Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: I stared at the calendar on my phone, my thumb hovering over the RSVP for my stepdad’s birthday trip. My mom’s voice echoed in my head, “It would mean a lot if you came. We’re finally feeling like a real family.” I wanted to be there, to laugh with my stepbrother, to show I cared. But my phone buzzed again—an email from my supervisor at the legal aid office. “Court session rescheduled to Friday morning. Your client’s future depends on this.” I felt my stomach twist. I’d promised my client I’d fight for her, that I’d be there, no matter what. But the family trip was the same weekend, and missing the start would mean missing the bonding everyone kept saying we needed. My mom’s hopeful eyes, my client’s desperate trust—both weighed on me. I could feel the pressure building, my heart racing as I tried to imagine disappointing either side. I sat on my bed, torn, unable to move, knowing I had to choose but wishing I didn’t have to.
